accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: William Cobbs Letters, 1827-1841, are part of Lynchburg (Va.) Chancery Cause: John Motley & wife, Etc. vs. John P. Cobbs, Etc. [1848-002] and are digitized and available through the Chancery Records Index on the website of the Library of Virginia. The image range for the letters within the case is roughly image 111-153. Please use digital images.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The original chancery cause came in through a transfer of court records which was described and processed by the local record department as part of the Chancery digitization project. The identified letters where then photocopied and gifted to the private papers department where they were described as a personal papers collection.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical Information
bioghist.p: William Cobbs was born March 2, 1792 in Campbell County, Virginia. He attended Hampden-Sydney College. After graduating, Cobbs managed his father's plantations in Campbell and Bedford Counties and his business activities in Kanawha Salines in present-day West Virginia. In 1828, he purchased Poplar Forest from Thomas Jefferson's grandson, Francis Eppes. Cobbs died September 6, 1852 in Bedford County, Virginia.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: William Cobbs Letters, 1827-1841, consist of correspondence used as evidence in the Lynchburg, Va., Chancery cause styled John Motley & wife, Etc. vs. John P. Cobbs, Etc. which excuses William of inadequately fulfilling his role as executor to Robert Cobbs, his father's, estate.

The letters are primarily between William Cobbs and William R. Cox and concern Cox's management of his finances and primarily concern William Cobbs' affairs as an enslaver. The correspondence highlight white enslaver's treatment of enslaved Black individuals as chattel. Many of the letters concern the most advantageous hiring out agreements for Harry, George and Peter, three Black men enslaved by Cobbs. Additionally, there are mentions of Harry's poor mental health, the self-emancipation of Ned and Tom and their pursuit to flee to Ohio or Canada, death of Moses, and sale of Stephen.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: The chancery suit, John Motley and wife and others versus John P. Cobbs and others, can be found in the Local Records Collection at the Library of Virginia. The index number is Chancery Cause 1848-002.
See also: Robert Lewis Cobbs letters, 1817

dsc.head: Contents List
dsc.p: Listed are the letters which include the correspondent and recipient; date; and image range for the letter in the Lynchburg (Va.) Chancery Causes: John Motley & wife, Etc. vs. John P. Cobbs, Etc. [1848-002] available digitally through the Chancery Records Index

did.unittitle: Letter - William R. Cox to William Cobbs: 6 January 1827 [Images 129-131]

scopecontent.p: Concerns Cox's family sickness, his home burning down, loss of an enslaved individual [unnamed], conducting Cobbs' business and bringing suits before the court for unpaid notes

did.unittitle: Letter - William Cobbs to William R. Cox: 7 March 1827 [Images 132-134]

scopecontent.p: Concerns the transportation of an unnamed woman [possibly Harriet] Cobbs has enslaved

did.unittitle: Letter - William R. Cox to William Cobbs: 13 May 1827 [Images 135-136]

scopecontent.p: Concerns Harriet and inability to transport her to Cobbs' homes, and the poor health of Moses

did.unittitle: Letter - R.E. Putney to William Cobbs: 15 August 1827 [Images 137-138]

scopecontent.p: Concerns Ned and Tom self-emancipating and believes they will make their way to Ohio or perhaps Canada and plans to pursue and advertise for their return

did.unittitle: Letter - William Cobbs to William R. Cox: 28 September 1827 [Images 139-141]

scopecontent.p: Concerns additional information about the pursuit of Ned and Tom and the belief that only a sufficient reward would ensure their apprehension. Notes Ned as being about 33 or 24 and Tom and 27 to 29. Believes the reward should be set to $200-300.

did.unittitle: Letter - Charles L. Cobbs to William Cobbs: 28 December 1827 [Images 142-144]

scopecontent.p: Concerns ploughing and business, appeal from Harry to not be separated from his wife who is enslaved by Charles Cobb,

did.unittitle: Letter - William R. Cox to William Cobbs: 8 February 1829[Images 145-146]

scopecontent.p: Concerns the death of Moses, and the drowning of a Peter Grant

did.unittitle: Letter - William R. Cox to William Cobbs: 27 January 1830 [Images 147-149]

scopecontent.p: Concerns the hiring out of Stephen and his wife [unnamed], difficulty in hiring out Harry due to mental health difficulties

did.unittitle: Letter - William Cobbs to William R. Cox: 25 December 1830 [Images 150-151]

scopecontent.p: Inability to hire out Harry due to his mental health and willingness to sell Harry is the opportunity is available

did.unittitle: Letter - William R. Cox to William Cobbs: 9 January 1831 [Images 152- 153]

scopecontent.p: Concerns hiring out of George to Lewis Ruffner and Harry to Putney

did.unittitle: Letter - William R. Cox to William Cobbs: 24 January 1832 [Images 111-112]

scopecontent.p: Concerns the hiring out of Harry, Peter, George

did.unittitle: Letter - William R. Cox to William Cobbs: 6 January 1833 [Images 113-114]

scopecontent.p: Concerns the hiring out of Harry, Peter, George. Unable to hire out Harry due to concerns about his mental health? Notes both George and Peter and in poor health.

did.unittitle: Letter - William R. Cox to William Cobbs: 27 January 1833 [Images 115-116]

scopecontent.p: Again corresponds about the difficulty in hiring out Harry due to his anxiety about being away from home [Lynchburg, Va.]

did.unittitle: Letter - William Cobbs to William R. Cox: 31 December 1835 [Images 117-118]

scopecontent.p: Concerns poor health of his daughter and himself as well as the hiring out of Peter and George

did.unittitle: Letter - William R. Cox to William Cobbs: 28 January 1840 [Images 119-120]

scopecontent.p: Concerns the purchase history of Steven, death of Moses, Ned and Tom as freedom seekers,

did.unittitle: Letter - William R. Cox to William Cobbs: 7 January 1841 [Images 121-122]

scopecontent.p: Concerns the purchase history of Steven, death of Moses, Ned and Tom as freedom seekers as well as George being badly scalded
